subject: RE: [junit] Counting junit test failures/errors

messageBody:
Right or wrong is not something I want to argue here. but thanks for
people's input.



Basically it is as Cedric suggested. We lost our way for a while and of
course ended up with a few failed tests (~20 out of 2000) after a large
refactoring period. I'm now trying to get on top of it while still trying
to keep the progress trackers happy which means I can't spend an
indeterminate amount of time fixing the tests without appearing not to
progress on the primary requirement set. So, I'd like to cap the test
errors/failures as they are now and reduce it over time as we fix the broken
code/tests over a (short) period or time, until we get to 0 and "realise"
the real benefits of an automated test suite.



Until we get it to 0 issues I need to cap it. At the end of the day though
I agree wholeheartedly with J.B. but I have to get back to "the perfect
world" first and at least failing the build when we get worse than we are is
a start.



Thanks again. Looks like I'll be delving into the code at some stage soon,
or I'll play the TestResult-Enforcer personally for a little while.



Greg.









_____

From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of J.
B. Rainsberger
Sent: Saturday, 26 August 2006 5:41 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Counting junit test failures/errors



Simon Chappell wrote:

> On 8/25/06, Greg Irvine <greg.irvine@ <mailto:greg.irvine%40thalesatm.com>
thalesatm.com
> <mailto:greg.irvine%40thalesatm.com>> wrote:
> > Any suggestions on how I might count the total number of test
> failures and
> > errors in a build in order to fail the build at a certain threshold
> rather
> > than more 0 failures?
>
> No idea. You have the code, dive in and code up a storm. :-)

You'd have to have the Ant folks, but I believe Simon is correct: you'd
have to enhance the Ant <junit> task. You could add a property for that,
I suppose.

Is that really what you want, though? Do you want to tolerate, say, 10
test failures? What if you only have 10 tests? 100? 1000? (I know you
might not have these problems /now/....)

> > The <junit> task seems to only set a fail/error property and not the
> number
> > of failures in a test case.
>
> Yes, that's the way it works. I'm thinking it's by design, on the
> belief that you either want the first thing that fails or everything
> that fails. Generally, I suspect, a few things that failed would be
> much less useful.

I work this way: either I tolerate test failures or I don't. I tolerate
test failures for customer tests, but not for programmer tests. I've
never wanted to tolerate "a few" failures, for any value of "a few" in
code that I committed to source control.
